text:
Hi Lucy! Great to chat with you! A little about myself; I'm Kat, a Character Animator who's been working in London at various studios since I graduated from The Arts University Bournemouth in 2013. I've worked at Framestore, DNEG, Mikros, Blue Zoo, and Studio AKA to name a few! My current job sees me at DNEG Feature Animation working on "Ron's Gone Wrong" a feature film in partnership with Locksmith Animation.
Looking forward to our mentorship!
Oh crikey, thats an incredible amount of experience !! Thank you so much for doing this !
haha, it sounds more impressive than it is, trust me!
I'd love to hear more about yourself, too! Are you currently studying, and if so where? ^^
I'm a third year student at Escape Studios in London ^^
I want to be a creature animator so you having worked at Framestore and DNEG is super rad !
I can set us up a dropbox if you like, so if you have any anim you'd like feedback on you can drop it in there and I'll get some feedback your way?
I'm also happy to answer any other questions you might have along the way!
Ah yes please that would be amazing !!
Oh prepare to be spammed then haha
In regards to the working environment at DNEG, what's it like ? And is there any sort of pipeline you follow in regards to animation ?
what email should I use for you to set up the dropbox with?

As for your questions. We have a pipeline that is unique to DNEG that we use to pass our work on to the next departments! But I'm assuming you mean workflow?

In Features we tend to get launched on our shots by the directors first. They'll tell us the brief of what they want to see in the shot, and what acting beats they really want us to hit. Then, I'll normally either go straight into blocking, or if it's something where I feel like reference might help, I'll book some time in our reference room and film myself acting out the shot, then pick the best takes. We'll normally show blocking a couple of times before it's approved. It then goes into IP (In Progress) which is when we spline it until it's almost finished. As soon as it's nearly there and it's selling all the main acting beats, we'll get approval from Directors on IP and then it moves into Polish which is where we get to tidy up, add those little final touches that make the shot feel special and great ^^

This is a pretty typical workflow for Features, but for VFX it tends to work a little differently, mainly because directors tend to prefer seeing things in spline straight from the beginning, instead of stepped block. So your blocking is normally a little more refined!
